_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary

1. Accidental Release Prevention Policies

Wilbur-Ellis Company, Willows has developed a risk management program and an emergency response plan to address the requirements of 40 CFR 68 of the Clean Air Act. Wilbur-Ellis Company, Willows is diligent in the handling of all chemicals and is dedicated to the safety of its employees and the neighboring community. Wilbur-Ellis Company, Willows staff is trained and utilize equipment to monitor the facility and provide safeguards, for safely storing anhydrous ammonia, conducting anhydrous mixing operations to produce aqueous ammonia, and storing and distributing aqueous ammonia. 

Wilbur-Ellis Company, Willows has a long standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as personnel training and consideration of safety in the design, operation, and maintenance of the Anhydrous Ammonia Conversion System and the Aqueous Ammonia Storage System. Wilbur-Ellis Company, Willows policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances. 

2. Stationary Source and Regulated Substances

Wilbur-Ellis Company, Willows is located at 6504 County Road 57, Willows, California in the county of Glenn. The primary activity at the Facility is the conversion of anhydrous ammonia to aqueous ammonia, storage, and sale of fertilizers, in addition to, the sale of pre-packaged agricultural chemicals to farmers.

Anhydrous ammonia used for conversion is received, stored, and used in the production of aqueous ammonia, which is distributed as a crop production nutrient. Anhydrous ammonia is received by truck and stored in one 18,000 gallon storage tank (bullet) and one 15,000 gallon storage tank (bullet) at the site. The maximum quantity of anhydrous ammonia handled in this process is 154,242 pounds.

Aqua ammonia (24% of ammonia by weight) is stored in two 125,000 gallon above ground tanks at t

he site. The maximum quantity of aqua ammonia stored at the facility is 250,000 gallons. The total quantity of ammonia present in the aqua ammonia, based on 24% active ingredient by weight, is 425,400 pounds. 

3. Hazard Assessment Summary/Offsite Consequence Analysis

Per 40 CFR 68 Regulations, the description covering the worst-case and alternative case release scenarios has been eliminated from the executive summary. Please refer to the Hazard Assessment report for the results of this analysis. 

-Risk Considerations

Ammonia is a toxic inhalation hazard; and thus, the use of anhydrous and aqueous ammonia has inherent potential risks to potentially reach sensitive populations within the community. The facility's identified potential risks for an ammonia release from its process are included in the off-site consequence analysis, Hazard Assessment, and Process Hazard Analysis (PHA). Facility RMP elements and other safety programs are structured to minimize the potential of a release from the identified risks.
   -The history of the Wilbur-Ellis Company, Willows (i.e., no CalARP-applicable anhydrous or aqueous ammonia releases) reflects the adequacy of the design and diligence of the plant staff in safely storing and distributing anhydrous and aqueous ammonia. 

4. Accidental Release Prevention Program 

As part of the implementation of this Risk Management Program, key Prevention Program elements were documented and implemented by Wilbur-Ellis Company, Willows to manage process safety issues associated with the use of anhydrous and aqueous ammonia. In addition, common industry standards, policies, and procedures are currently utilized to ensure safe practices are being performed.

The facility's maximum intended inventory of anhydrous ammonia is 154,242 lbs.  Therefore, the covered process has over the 10,000 lbs threshold quantity for EPA RMP and Cal/OSHA PSM.  The 500 lbs state threshold for the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Pro

gram is also exceeded.  As a result, the anhydrous ammonia covered process is subject to CalARP Program Level 3 and EPA RMP Program Level 3. 

The Anhydrous Ammonia Prevention Program 3 elements include:

   -Process Safety Information
   -Process Hazard Analysis
   -Operating Procedures
   -Training
   -Mechanical Integrity
   -Management of Change
   -Pre-Startup Safety Review
   -Compliance Audits
   -Incident Investigation
   -Employee Participation
   -Hot Work Permit
   -Contractors

In addition, key emergency response elements were addressed in the Business Emergency Plan. See EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM below.

The facility's maximum storage of ammonia in the aqueous solution is 425,400 lb.  Therefore, it is over the 20,000 lbs threshold (20% or greater concentration) for EPA RMP and the 500 lbs (all concentrations) state threshold for California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program.  Wilbur-Ellis Company, Willows is not subject to Cal/OSHA PSM or Program 3 requirement due to the fact that the concentration of aqueous ammonia managed at the Facility is 24% and the Cal/OSHA PSM threshold quantity of aqueous ammonia is only for concentrations greater than 44%. For the reasons mentioned above, the Aqueous Ammonia Storage Tank is subject to CalARP Program Level 2 and EPA RMP Program Level 2.

The Aqueous Ammonia Prevention Program 2 elements include:

   -Safety Information
   -Hazard Review
   -Operating Procedures
   -Training
   -Maintenance
   -Compliance Audits
   -Incident Investigation

5. Five-Year Accident History

There have been no EPA-applicable releases of ammonia at Wilbur-Ellis Company, Willows in the past five years.

6. Emergency Response Program

Wilbur-Ellis Company, Willows is not a First Responder.  Employees are trained to evacuate and call 911 in case of an emergency.  Wilbur-Ellis Company, Willows will coordinate with local Fire Department and First Responders. Wilbur-Ellis Company, Willows ha

s filed a Business Emergency Plan to help coordinate with local responders.
An Emergency Action Plan (EAP) that meets the requirements of the CCR Title 8 §3220 is in place.

7. External Events Analysis Information

Pursuant to the requirements of California Health & Safety Code, Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5, §2745.7(q); the following external events analysis information shall be submitted:  

-The types of natural and human caused external events considered in PHA Section 2760.2 or Hazard Review Section 2755.2.  
   
   The Facility's 2009 PHA and HR is in the process of being reviewed and updated. Section 8.a. of this RMP will be corrected when the PHA review and updates are completed (targeted completion in 2014). During the June 2009 PHA and HR a broad list of external events was considered by the Team.  General events external to the plant that can conceivably cause a release of anhydrous or aqueous ammonia were addressed.  The External Events that were considered credible include, but are not limited to, earthquake, vandalism, sabotage, external fire, human error/misoperation, and vehicle impact. 

-The estimated magnitude or scope of external events which were considered. If not known, the owner or operator of the stationary source shall work closely with the AA to determine what is required. If seismic events are applicable, the parameters used in the consideration of the seismic analysis and which edition of the Uniform Building Code was used when the process was designed.
    
   The magnitudes of the external events considered are detailed within the PHA Worksheets and were qualitatively risk-ranked by the PHA Team.

-For each external event, with a potential to create a release of a regulated substance that will reach an endpoint offsite, apply 

1) The expected date of completion of any changes resulting from the PHA;
2) Major hazards identified;
3) Process controls in use;
4) Mitigation systems in use;
5) Monitoring and detecti

on systems in use; and,
6) Changes since the last Hazard Review (HR) or PHA

8. Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Wilbur-Ellis is committed to continuously making safety improvements. To improve the safety of the ammonia system, Wilbur Ellis is in the process of developing a more comprehensive anhydrous ammonia inspection checklist for the bullet tank system and nurse tanks. The comprehensive checklist will include daily, weekly, and annual inspection frequencies, including visual and non-destructive tests to evaluate the mechanical integrity of the tanks, valves, piping, etc. At a minimum, inspection frequencies will follow industry standards. Wilbur-Ellis is also implementing a facility wide comprehensive corrective action/preventative action (CAPA) log to track and facilitate completion of listed CAs on a timely basis. Recommended improvements and identified deficiencies from the  inspection checklists, compliance audits, and PHA studies will be included on the facility CAPA log along with the priority, employee responsible, and targeted completion dates. The Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) study has been conducted to examine mitigation measures to improve safety at the facility.  Planned changes to improve safety are listed as recommendations in the June 4th, 2009 PHA Report. Any outstanding recommendations will be addressed by December 2009.

9. Flammables: Worst Case

The use of flammable materials at Wilbur-Ellis Company, Willows is not encompassed by either the federal or state RMP requirements.  Therefore, this section is not applicable. 

10. Flammables: Alternative Release

The use of flammable materials at Wilbur-Ellis Company, Willows is not encompassed by either the federal or state RMP requirements.  Therefore, this section is not applicable.
